messages: 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (23:07): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: wow, you pretty much nailed it.
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (23:07): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: i'm glad i didn't specify the expansion algorithm, you came up with something quite interesting that i hadn't thought of
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (23:07): i was thinking of using an extensions to CSS
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (23:07): also, you don't need a registration mark in your example
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (23:08): the only other thing is you'd want to have the input elements update the items
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (23:10): e.g. onchange="dataNode.setAttribute('value', value)" value="&{this.getAttribute('value')}"
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (23:20): 65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c: interesting site for browser stats, though they really should show the data on a log scale
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (23:21): they could show more browsers that way too
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (23:21): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: that would certainly make it easier to see the trends
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (23:22): I'm not sure why I bothered putting the registrationmark in, since it's useless without scripting

69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (23:23): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: it's useful when the data regenerates and hits a different set of conditions, but you want the same element to be used for different parts of the two conditions, yeah
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (23:23): 65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c: these stats also don't include the iPhone browser, which i believe would be interesting to see

65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (23:24): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: if you mean these stats: <http://marketshare.hitslink.com/>, then they lump the iPhone browser in with Safari, but you can see it in the OS share stats
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (23:25): (you can also see Nintendo Wii in the OS share stats)
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (23:25): ah, so they do
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (23:25): but those don't appear on the line graph
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (23:25): pah
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (23:25): do you know if there's a way to download those numbers without site scraping?
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (23:25): reads old Joel Strategy Letters over supper
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (23:25): Oops, I missed the bit where the algorithm does useful stuff if you regenerate the structure without any registrationmarks
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (23:26): (they should be required reading)
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (23:26): or without downloading each page in turn?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (23:26): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: that was the Levenberg breakthrough. :-)
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (23:27): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: http://www.google.fi/search?q=site%3Ajoelonsoftware.com+strategy+letter top six hits
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (23:27): (btw for what it's worth i can confirm that these marketshare.hitslink.com stats are remarkably high quality)
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (23:28): HTML5 (unlike XHTML2) gets plugging into existing network right
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (23:30): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: btw, what ARIA has going for it over HTML5 plus XBL is that ARIA doesn't disrupt existing systems

65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (23:33): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: they do show a surprising amount of month-to-month variance which seems unlikely to reflect real changes in user base in at least some cases, but since it's based on usage, not count of unique users, I guess that could just reflect variability in browsing habits
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (23:33): Joel's letter # VI confuses me
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (23:34): afaik Google has at least two systems that compile languages down to JavaScript (with the source languages being Java and JavaScript respectively)
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (23:34): 65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c: yeah, I noticed that he didn't mention GWT
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (23:35): there's also less reason on the web for a single library-level SDK to dominate, since there is no bundling/integration issue
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (23:48): btw, http://marketshare.hitslink.com/report.aspx?qprid=2 must be heavily U.S.-biased
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (23:48): there's no way the iPhone could have more market share than S60 globally
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (23:49): http://vowe.net/archives/008814.html
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (23:50): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: it's usage share, so it's possible if iPhone users browse a lot more per user
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (23:53): I guess WinCE shows up pretty high too though
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (23:54): iPhone users use the web way more than any other cell phone
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (23:55): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: as i understand it it's not HTML5+XBL vs <div>+ARIA, it's HTML5 vs <div>+ARIA

69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (23:56): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: the XBL is only required if you want to start making custom new widgets, which isn't anywhere near as important in this case afaict
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (23:57): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: ARIA is about retrofitting custom JS+div widgets with accessibility if I've understood correctly
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (00:00): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: XBL is also required if you want to make native HTML5 widgets looks kewl the way your art dept required
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (00:00): http://philip.html5.org/demos/datatemplate/experimental/002.html - now somewhat more elaborate and even more likely to be wrong
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (00:00): What'd be really nice is a scripted implementation to test things with :-)
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (00:01): Oops, I think the <rule condition="categories"><nest filter="category"></rule> is unnecessary
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (00:02): (but the <rule condition="items" mode="summary"><nest id="item_filter" mode="summary"></rule> is still necessary)
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:02): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: dude, you kick ass. this is exactly what we need to check the spec makes sense.
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:02): 002 has two item_filter IDs
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:03): also, holy crap, i hadn't thought of modifying the <nest> dynamically
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:03): that's awesome
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:03): the spec will have to say the UA must monitor the template, too

b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (00:03): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: as far as I can tell, if someone replaces HTML 4.01 buttons, radio buttons and checkboxes with divitis, they'll going to want to do the same with sliders even when those are natively available
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (00:04): Fixed item_filters
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:04): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: yeah, can't argue with that
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:04): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: let's hope xbl2 gets implemented soon :-/
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (00:05): some of the kewlness can be achieved just through CSS styling of standard controls
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (00:05): although browsers vary in how much of that they allow
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (00:05): it's doable for buttons and text fields, but not really for checkboxes or radio buttons afaict
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:06): yeah
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (00:08): you can style them in Safari 3 by setting "-webkit-appearance: none" but I don't think there is any way in IE
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:14): did i get unsubscribed from public-html or something
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:14): there's been no e-mail to it for hours
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (00:18): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: It's been surprisingly quiet
